NFTs are just the wrapper that makes it digital and easily transferable. But this happens already. So the more money that's spent in the game, either through cosmetics, through play, to earn mechanics, through X, Y and Z, that money through primary and secondary revenues, will be flown into these assets, and then the cash flow will come back to the users. speaker: F
text: Yeah. First and foremost, this was going to happen at some point. This was an inevitability. When you have royalties on the protocols or on the platform side of two to two and a half percent, depending on the marketplace you're interacting with, and you have royalties on the project side of between five and twelve and a half percent, it makes it difficult for people to get on board with the process. You're starting off the position, 10% in the whole. You don't feel aligned correctly. You feel like the fees are just chopping away at the value of your asset. More or less unprecedented for secondary sales. You can argue primary sales and auction houses are high, but in terms of secondary sales, there's a discussion between ownership of the asset and just rent harvesting on the asset for the creator. So this was going to happen anyway. There's going to be a battle at some point. The answer, in my opinion, is that fees have to come down. There will be attrition of fees. You cannot have seven and a half to 10% forever. Right. The more volume that a project does, the more primary and secondary revenue that they do, the less percentages they need to take to keep their business sustainable. So that's clear that it's going to come down whether people like it or not. But 0% is probably too much, because at 0% you have a disruption of alignment between the project founders and the ecosystem and the holders. If there's no direct incentive to keep the project going, then you start to see people either slack off or show interest elsewhere. But there was a good point I made online the other day. I can't remember who said it, but on the flip side, as a devil's advocate, having royalties is incentivizing volatility as opposed to value accrual. And that may not also be the best idea. So this is a very new, again, very new space, very new debates. I think a big portion of it, the pushback that ash was talking about earlier, I think, will come more. So from the protocol side, I think that you're going to see a lot of projects starting to build royalties on chain immutable, and if a platform doesn't want to adhere to the protocol, then they can't list the asset. So I think it's going to become much more correct. As opposed to previously.
